channel.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
channel.description:
If you could go back in time to when you were 10 years old and tell yourself just one thing what would you say?
NOT the Lottery numbers!

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: Note-anator
item.description:
Folks, if I could suggest a great book on ADD, it is called “Driven to Distraction”. It goes over what ADD and ADHD are, and some of the markers that one should look for if they think they may have it.

It is unfortunate, that ADD and ADHD have become a catch phrase for anyone with a fast mind, or for a kid with a behavior issues - Lots of youth have been given Ritalin, or Dexedrine, when what they needed was more involvement with their parents doing things together. A bit of discipline, and time blowing off some pent up energy doing whatever. Diet does play a role also, but that is here or there.

A high achieving student, suddenly having his marks plummet, does NOT qualify for ADD, if there was not former, long haul symptoms. (As obvious as that seems, some have been prescribed meds they should have never been on.

There are many things that can be a factor in mimic behavior of ADD, as we go through various stages/situations/stresses/nutrition available though life. Again my friends, it is the long haul history of the various markers that are important to pay attention to.

(Bolteh, no worries about the comment brother - it would have been perfectly appropriate if I was saying was what you first thought I was saying. (perhaps I should have made the rapid switch thing more apparent, and not a one off bracket) There is a lot of banana oil that gets shuffled around the net and it is good for folks to call people on BS. Cheers)

EDIT

CatzEyes93:

some grow out of it thru puberty.

Yes… Some do seem to. (Though i have to wonder if it is merely learning to adapt? I would love to see peer reviewed medical journal article on this)

Read full topic
item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: gugamilare
item.description:
X_Mastershot_X:

^ wait that still happens to me…

:fffuuu::fffuuu::fffuuu:
You lost the best part and kept the worst? WTH!

You still might not have ADD, because I don’t, I guess. I read an article that said that human intelligence can be separated into, IIRC, 8 kinds of intelligence. One of them is logic, another is social intelligence. I think that I just have the former above the average and the latter below the average. Maybe you have a similar problem. IMO, not a big deal, though, if you learn to live with it.

Read full topic

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: gugamilare
item.description:
Note-anator:

Bolteh, it is called associative thinking. In average folks, they track rather well, because their minds are not in hyper mode.

If you are talking about baseball uniforms, you mostly stay on task. With some folks, (Such as ADD folks) you mention baseball uniforms, and suddenly, not only are they thinking about baseball uniforms, but about the manufacturing of high quality baseballs. (This switch happens in a pico second) […]

I’m wondering if I have this… maybe, but in a different way.

In some complicated conversations I fail to express myself, I have a thought and can’t find the words. This is not a bad thing when writing like now I write a paragraph, go to another paragraph, and go back when I remember something. Like writing two paragraphs at the same time But, in a conversation, in some situations I just can’t remember or process the arguments I already have in my head, it might even take minutes. Other times, the group changes the subject and the rest of the conversation give me something that I could have said back then. In these cases I don’t go back on the conversation, because people complain, instead I just get frustrated and stay quiet.

I guess I’m just slow to process informations.

By the way, I once talked to a psychologist (in order to be tested to get a driver license) and she was quite impressed with the speed I finished a couple of tests. Then I said to her that I was distracted. She made a weird face and said “No, you are not.” and I was shocked. She said that I fail to pay attention in details, and that I have a selective memory: I remember what I want to remember. I seem to have no problem in focusing on something I want to.

My sister tells me “I’m going to wherever” and I just think “Why should I care?”. If you ask me where my sister went 2 seconds (I mean literally 2 seconds) after that, I would say I don’t remember. If you ask me that after one minute, I would say “She didn’t say me anything. She didn’t even talk to me today.” It’s not on purpose, I need to force myself to care in these situations to remember, that is not as easy as it looks like.

Read full topic

item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: X_Mastershot_X
item.description:
Note-anator:

The list is long and distinguished… It would take a while to give you the whole list, keeping in mind that everyone is different, and that usually, there is concomadant other minor disabilities that seem to pair with it, but for starter

Missing normal social cues
Impulsitivity issues
Thinking very differently than other people.
Being brilliant in one area, and a complete failure in others (Such as staying on task)
Impaired self worth
Thinking yourself stupid, because you can not seem to master some of the basic things that “average” people do.
Not being average.
Challenges in learning

ETC. Sure you can meet lots of folks, but it is harder to relate on a “I am normal” level.

I think i had this back in my childhood. Not sure what i did but i got rid of it…
… I still miss being able to think like that

Read full topic

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
Bolteh: You missed this portion: “(This switch happens in a pico second)”

In ADD/ADHD, conversation evolution happens at lightning speed. You might still be on the same sentence and they’re already several hundred generations down the line.

Oh, and Carmen Miranda died in 1955.

(That’s what Note-anator is referring to. The evolution in the ADD/ADHD person’s mind can see the line of events to Carmen Miranda’s death, but to the outside person, the apparent non-sequitur comes out of left field. Like steroids.)

Read full topic
item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: Bolteh
item.description:
DansonDelta40:

Hmm… makes me wonder whether I might also suffer from ADD. Looks strangely familiar, all of this…

Of course it sounds familiar, what he’s explaining is perfectly normal conversational evolution. Everyone I know does this. If you talk about baseball uniforms, it’s pretty normal to at some point get to the sport itself, and thus you get to talk about the equipment, and then you talk about the companies that make them, and then you just talk about the different companies that make all sorts of sports equipment. And if you keep talking afte this point, you’ll end up with astrophysics and its impact on Kim Jong Il’s mental health.

I for one hope Note-anator isn’t a real doctor, because if he is, all his patients must have ADD or ADHD.

Read full topic
item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: DansonDelta40
item.description:
Note-anator:

Bolteh, it is called associative thinking. In average folks, they track rather well, because their minds are not in hyper mode.

If you are talking about baseball uniforms, you mostly stay on task. With some folks, (Such as ADD folks) you mention baseball uniforms, and suddenly, not only are they thinking about baseball uniforms, but about the manufacturing of high quality baseballs. (This switch happens in a pico second) Then they think something like… I wonder if that is REAL leather on the ball. Then, an article about feed lot cattle comes to mind, (About how poor the leather can be) and then there is the free floating thought about improving cattle hide to make better baseballs by using various hormone additive in cattle feed. From there, the thought may (or may not) circle back to baseball players who are doped up, and before they know it - The next thing out of their mouth, is a comment on this or that ball player who was caught doping. The person in the conversation next to them, is baffled how conversation when from green and grey, to Buba learning tango lessons fron a bad man named Brutus.

That is one of the reasons that ADD folks lives are in chaos. The impulse thing is utter frustration. I used to say things that were horrid to folks, and not realize that I had crossed a social boundary. (My poor Ex-wife. My God… I cringe when I think about how many times I hurt her by having something fall out of my head without consider the impact, or for that matter, the truth of what the thought was.

Shrugs.

As to the rest, met up with an Add fellow today; he is 22 and suffering from social issues. Thank whatever God there may be, that he is at least aware he has it, and did not find out until he was divorcing that it had been a major issue in your marriage/life break down.

Hmm… makes me wonder whether I might also suffer from ADD. Looks strangely familiar, all of this…

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: bur
item.description:
I usually just sit back and be silent when that happens. I have a hard time focussing on what people are saying as it is, let alone when there’s people yelling from all directions :x

And Note-anator, sounds familiar :3 When I talk with my dad, we can go from talking about Formula 1 to, say religion or ancient history and everything in between over the course of half an hour.

item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: Bolteh
item.description:
Ehm, not sure what you’re on about, but I’m talking about these situations:

[COLOR=‘Black’]…A[COLOR=‘black’]…B
C [COLOR=‘Gray’]||||| D
[COLOR=‘Black’]…E[COLOR=‘black’]…F

E = me

A, F and D are talking about cars
B, C and E are talking about music

So what you get is two totally different conversations being launched across the table, crossing one another. Each participant feels the urge to make sure that their conversation is louder than the other one, so you end up with a bunch of people nearly yelling at each other.

Most of my relatives are champions at that >_>

Read full topic
item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: Note-anator
item.description:
Bolteh:

I hate crossfire conversations in group >_>

I don’t understand why people do that… When I was out for dinner for my mate’s birthday this weekend, we were with 9, and we all had one continuous conversation with each other, but why do so many people start splitting groups in half and start talking about different things all together?

At this point i usually just bugger off to play guitar on my own.

Bolteh, it is called associative thinking. In average folks, they track rather well, because their minds are not in hyper mode.

If you are talking about baseball uniforms, you mostly stay on task. With some folks, (Such as ADD folks) you mention baseball uniforms, and suddenly, not only are they thinking about baseball uniforms, but about the manufacturing of high quality baseballs. (This switch happens in a pico second) Then they think something like… I wonder if that is REAL leather on the ball. Then, an article about feed lot cattle comes to mind, (About how poor the leather can be) and then there is the free floating thought about improving cattle hide to make better baseballs by using various hormone additive in cattle feed. From there, the thought may (or may not) circle back to baseball players who are doped up, and before they know it - The next thing out of their mouth, is a comment on this or that ball player who was caught doping. The person in the conversation next to them, is baffled how conversation when from green and grey, to Buba learning tango lessons fron a bad man named Brutus.

That is one of the reasons that ADD folks lives are in chaos. The impulse thing is utter frustration. I used to say things that were horrid to folks, and not realize that I had crossed a social boundary. (My poor Ex-wife. My God… I cringe when I think about how many times I hurt her by having something fall out of my head without consider the impact, or for that matter, the truth of what the thought was.

Shrugs.

As to the rest, met up with an Add fellow today; he is 22 and suffering from social issues. Thank whatever God there may be, that he is at least aware he has it, and did not find out until he was divorcing that it had been a major issue in your marriage/life break down.

Read full topic

item.description:
CatzEyes93:

News flash: I just asked my 12 year old this question… he said that he would tell his 10 year old self to “shut up!”.

BHAHAHAHAHAHAHAAAAAHAHAHAHAAAAAAA!!!

:lol:

Well, the funniest thing is it actually makes sense I would also love to tell myself to shut up at some points in time.

item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...

item.title: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
item.dc:creator: gugamilare
item.description:
Note-anator:

Missing normal social cues
Impulsitivity issues
Thinking very differently than other people.
Being brilliant in one area, and a complete failure in others (Such as staying on task)
Impaired self worth
Thinking yourself stupid, because you can not seem to master some of the basic things that “average” people do.
Not being average.
Challenges in learning

Burbinator:

Check, check, check, check, check, check and check.

Maybe I should get myself tested some day

Also, I find that I can’t handle attention from more than one or two people. I have a very hard time participating in a conversation in a group, less so if I know the majority of them quite well.

About 80% of that list applies to me as well. I wouldn’t consider “not being average” a disability, though, it’s something that makes me proud of myself. I also have difficulties sometimes in group conversations, but it varies a lot depending on the group and on the subject. In every group there is one or two who stay quieter then the rest in each conversation, I don’t see a big problem here.

The first time I suspected about having ADD was around ten years ago, when I first heard about this disorder. Back then I also heard that Einstein was known to have had this disorder, so I didn’t worry about it. I might or not have ADD, I don’t really care. I’ve learned (well, still learning actually) to deal with my own social problems with lots of patience, persistence and willpower. Just always keep trying until you get it right and never give up. Never look down.

On topic, if I found my 10 year old self, that is what I would have told myself. Never look down. Not only metaphorically but also literally. There is no need to be afraid of people. I would also tell myself not to worry about the bullying I would suffer from 5th to 8th grades. “Because words can’t change who you are. You will do and say stupid things, lots of times, prepare yourself. But, when that happens, don’t stay there crying over the spilled milk. Breath deeply, get a cloth and rub it. If there is nothing you can do, just smile and move on, leave it there. In the end it just doesn’t make difference.”

I have the impression that everything serious I say sounds dramatic but I really have no desire to change that :rolleyes:

EDIT:

CatzEyes93:

My 12 year old’s biggest hang up is missing social cues. He has no idea when people are looking at him weird cuz he is saying or doing something stupid.

Haha, sounds like my cousin. Or my younger self. My cousin seems not to even realize that people are looking at him weird. I, on the other hand, realized I did something stupid, and took a long time to realize it (sometimes only after a couple of minutes).

Read full topic
item.source: Go back in time and tell your 10 year old self something...
